Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER: Robust longitudinal characterization of brain oscillations in the first 3 years of life

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The human brain undergoes rapid and profound changes during the first 3 years of life, which accompany the emergence of new cognitive skills, including remembering and recognizing faces and objects, acquiring vocabularies, and focusing attention on the task at hand, among others. While such a rich repertoire of functions requires the coordination of multiple brain regions, little is known about how changes in the brain's electrical activity across different brain regions correlate with changes in behavior. This knowledge gap is in part due to methodological limitations imposed by the predominant brain imaging method, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). fMRI not only requires infants or toddlers to remain still or asleep during the observation, but also cannot directly measure rapid changes in neuronal activity at a high temporal resolutions (millisecond). With recent technological and computational advances, it has become possible to overcome these technical barriers and obtain direct measurements of brain electrical activity in behaving infants. With the support of the National Science foundation, Dr Stamoulis and colleagues at the Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience at Boston Children's Hospital/Harvard Medical School, will have the rare opportunity to systematically characterize development-related changes in neural signals derived from longitudinal hdEEG data acquired in infants and toddlers repeatedly across 3 to 36 months of age using a number of advanced computational approaches. This study will provide fundamental information regarding how the brain changes across early development. Findings from this project are also expected to help educate families on how early experiences shape the brain and facilitate cognitive functions, and will inspire the development of new courses and instructional materials to educate students, researchers and clinicians on the relationships between behavioral and neural mechanisms of cognitive development.

The project is an ambitious attempt at characterizing changes in the developing human brain by analysing high-density electroencephalography (hdEEG) data collected from the same infants across the first three years of life using source localization and frequency analysis of neural oscillations within and between different functional brain regions. The investigation will focus on characterizing oscillatory waveforms of brain electrical signals originating from different spatial locations across multiple time points during early development. The power of these waveforms in different frequency bands, e.g. theta, alpha, beta, and gamma power, are known to emerge at different time points during early development and to be associated with variations in external stimuli, information processing demands, and behaviors. However, age-related changes in the dominant oscillation frequency, power and spatial distribution among brain regions have not been systematically characterized during this age range. Longitudinal high-density EEG data from about 200 typically developing infants at 3, 6, 9, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months of age will be analyzed under the same type of tasks and no-task conditions. Novel source analysis methods will be applied to hdEEGs, to extract and localize dominant sources and to decompose source signals into individual oscillation components and compare them across ages. Resting and functional networks and directional connectivities between identified sources will also be systematically quantified and compared across ages. This project is expected to provide a new source-based language for investigating human brain development using EEG and to reveal how neural signals change in time, frequency and brain spaces to enable infants to communicate with the world and to acquire new skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first few years of life represent a critical period of human development, during which the brain's structural and functional circuitry undergoes a dramatic reorganization to support the acquisition of increasingly complex cognitive skills. To date, topological changes in the developing brain's functional circuits have not been systematically characterized. This is in part due to the need for large samples, given substantial inter-brain variability as a result of unique experiences that may significantly impact at least some neural circuits. With the support of the National Science Foundation, this project has assembled and is currently analyzing several large electrophysiological datasets from the developing human brain. These include cross-sectional but high-dimensional (in duration) noninvasive electrophysiological (EEG) data and longitudinal (high-density; N> 400) EEGs, collected at multiple time points. The overarching goal of the investigation has been to systematically quantify age-related changes in fundamental aspects of neural circuitry, primarily during the first 3 years. These include cortical oscillations, which are integral components of neural activity and facilitate the interaction and coordination of functional brain networks across domains in response to cognitive demands and sensory inputs.

To date, we have shown that neural oscillations with distinct characteristic frequencies also have distinct developmental trajectories during the first few years of life, with higher non-linearities in age estimated at higher frequencies (>15 Hz) but quasi-linear trajectories at lower frequencies. This indicates that lower-frequency oscillations may develop earlier in life, potentially to facilitate functions that are critical to survival, such as low-level vision. In contrast, higher-frequency oscillations, particularly in frontal brain areas may develop later in life, with the emergency of higher-level functions. Neural oscillations may be adversely impacted by early life stressors, leading to cognitive deficits and developmental delays. To assess the impact of psychosocial neglect (a potentially significant stressor with long-term implications on cognitive function) on cortical oscillations and their networks, another already available longitudinal dataset from children reared in institutions in Romania has been investigated. This work has shown that early psychosocial neglect has profound, widespread and potentially irreversible adverse effects (at least in the short-run) on neural oscillations and their networks (Stamoulis, 2015; 2017).

Finally this project has also facilitated methodological advances, particularly the development of statistical models to describe the developmental, non-linear trajectories of these oscillations and probabilistic connectivity approaches that specifically address the issue of biological 'noise' in the developing brain's circuitry, and may thus be more robust to it than traditional methods, which in the presence of noise may lead to spurious findings. 

This project has provided substantial training opportunities for undergraduate and K-12 students. Specifically, 3 high-school students from groups underrepresented in STEM have participated in this project as summer research interns through Harvard Medical School's Project Sucess. During their internships, students had the opportunity to learn about the brain, how to analyze electrophysiological data and basic statistics and improved their scientific writing and presentation skills. In addition, 5 undergraduate students, including one student from an underrepresented group, have also participated in this project as research interns/assistants and have been trained in computational Neuroscience methods. Their work has led to two scientific manuscripts and multiple abstracts and presentations.
